sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
A system of linear equations in block matrix form is given below:

$$ \begin{bmatrix}2I & 3B\\A & 4I\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}x\\y \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix}5\\6 \end{bmatrix} $$

where I is the identity matrix, A is a 2x2 matrix with entries {1,0;-1,2} and B is a 2x2 matrix with entries {2,-1;0,3}. 

Find the values of x and y that satisfies the system of linear equations.
message_2:
First, let's write down the given matrices:

$$I = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & 1\end{bmatrix}, A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\-1 & 2\end{bmatrix}, B = \begin{bmatrix}2 & -1\\0 & 3\end{bmatrix}$$

Now, let's compute the products of the matrices:

$$2I = \begin{bmatrix}2 & 0\\0 & 2\end{bmatrix}, 3B = \begin{bmatrix}6 & -3\\0 & 9\end{bmatrix}, 4I = \begin{bmatrix}4 & 0\\0 & 4\end{bmatrix}$$

Now, we can write the system of linear equations as:

$$\begin{bmatrix}2 & 0 & 6 & -3\\0 & 2 & 0 & 9\\1 & 0 & 4 & 0\\-1 & 2 & 0 & 4\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\\y_1\\y_2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}5\\6\\6\\5\end{bmatrix}$$

This is equivalent to the following system of linear equations:

$$\begin{cases} 2x_1 + 6y_1 - 3y_2 = 5 \\ 2x_2 + 9y_2 = 6 \\ x_1 + 4y_1 = 6 \\ -x_1 + 2x_2 + 4y_2 = 5 \end{cases}$$

We can solve this system of linear equations using substitution or elimination method. Let's use the substitution method:

From the third equation, we have:

$$x_1 = 6 - 4y_1$$

Substitute this into the first and fourth equations:

$$2(6 - 4y_1) + 6y_1 - 3y_2 = 5$$
$$- (6 - 4y_1) + 2x_2 + 4y_2 = 5$$

Simplify the equations:

$$12 - 8y_1 + 6y_1 - 3y_2 = 5$$
$$-6 + 4y_1 + 2x_2 + 4y_2 = 5$$

$$-2y_1 - 3y_2 = -7$$
$$4y_1 + 2x_2 + 4y_2 = 11$$

Multiply the first equation by 2 and add it to the second equation:

$$-4y_1 - 6y_2 = -14$$
$$4y_1 + 2x_2 + 4y_2 = 11$$

$$2x_2 - 2y_2 = -3$$

Divide by 2:

$$x_2 - y_2 = -\frac{3}{2}$$

Now, substitute this into the second equation of the original system:

$$2x_2 + 9y_2 = 6$$

Substitute $x_2 - y_2 = -\frac{3}{2}$:

$$2(-\frac{3}{2} + y_2) + 9y_2 = 6$$

Simplify:

$$-3 + 2y_2 + 9y_2 = 6$$

$$11y_2 = 9$$

$$y_2 = \frac{9}{11}$$

Now, substitute this back into $x_2 - y_2 = -\frac{3}{2}$:

$$x_2 - \frac{9}{11} = -\frac{3}{2}$$

$$x_2 = -\frac{3}{2} + \frac{9}{11}$$

$$x_2 = \frac{-33 + 18}{22}$$

$$x_2 = -\frac{15}{22}$$

Now we have $x_2$ and $y_2$. We can substitute $y_1$ back into $x_1 = 6 - 4y_1$:

$$x_1 = 6 - 4\left(-\frac{15}{22}\right)$$

$$x_1 = 6 + \frac{60}{22}$$

$$x_1 = \frac{192}{22}$$

Now we have $x_1$ and $x_2$. Finally, substitute $x_1$ back into $x_1 + 4y_1 = 6$:

$$\frac{192}{22} + 4y_1 = 6$$

$$4y_1 = 6 - \frac{192}{22}$$

$$4y_1 = \frac{60}{22}$$

$$y_1 = \frac{15}{22}$$

Now we have all the values:

$$x = \begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}\frac{192}{22}\\-\frac{15}{22}\end{bmatrix}, y = \begin{bmatrix}y_1\\y_2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}\frac{15}{22}\\\frac{9}{11}\end{bmatrix}$$
